summary: Louis Stokes is mentioned in the context of payroll records and administrative documents related to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). He appears as an authorizing official on payroll authorization forms for HSCA staff members. These documents detail the employment, salary adjustments, and termination of various individuals working for the HSCA. The documents also include Final Determination Notifications from the Assassination Records Review Board regarding the postponement of certain information, specifically Social Security numbers, within HSCA staff payroll records to protect personal privacy. Stokes's role seems to be primarily administrative, involving the approval of personnel actions and ensuring compliance with payroll procedures within the HSCA.
significance: Louis Stokes's significance in the JFK context, based on these documents, is related to his role in the administrative and operational functions of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). He authorized payroll actions for HSCA staff, indicating his involvement in the committee's day-to-day operations. While the documents do not directly link him to specific findings or investigations related to the JFK assassination, his authorization of payroll suggests he was involved in the management of the committee's resources and personnel.
